methods.name: Dataset
methods.description: Interact with a dataset from the Google Cloud Datastore.

examples.caption: Connect to your local Datastore server.
The process.env.DATASTORE_HOST environment variable is also recognized. If set, you may omit the apiEndpoint option.

params.name: options.apiEndpoint
params.description: • Override the default API endpoint used to reach Datastore. This is useful for connecting to your local Datastore server (usually "http://localhost:8080").

methods.name: key
methods.description:
Helper to create a Key object, scoped to the dataset's namespace by default.

You may also specify a configuration object to define a namespace and path.

params.name: options
params.description: • Key path. To specify or override a namespace, you must use an object here to explicitly state it.

methods.name: createQuery
methods.description: Create a query from the current dataset to query the specified kind, scoped to the namespace provided at the initialization of the dataset.

methods.name: runInTransaction
methods.description: Run a function in the context of a new transaction. Transactions allow you to perform multiple operations, committing your changes atomically. When you are finished making your changes within the transaction, run the done() function provided in the callback function to commit your changes. See an example below for more information.

params.name: fn
params.description: • The function to run in the context of a transaction.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: get
methods.description: Retrieve the entities identified with the specified key(s) in the current transaction. Get operations require a valid key to retrieve the key-identified entity from Datastore.

examples.caption: Get a single entity.
examples.code:
var key = dataset.key(['Company', 123]);

dataset.get(key, function(err, entity) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
examples.code: transaction.get(key, function(err, entity) {});

examples.caption: Get multiple entities at once with a callback.
Or, get the entities as a readable object stream.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.entity
params.description: • Will return either a single Entity or a list of Entities.

exceptions.description: If at least one Key object is not provided.

methods.name: insert
methods.description: Maps to datastore/dataset#save, forcing the method to be insert.

methods.name: save
methods.description:
Insert or update the specified object(s). If a key is incomplete, its associated object is inserted and the original Key object is updated to contain the generated ID.

This method will determine the correct Datastore method to execute (upsert, insert, update, and insertAutoId) by using the key(s) provided. For example, if you provide an incomplete key (one without an ID), the request will create a new entity and have its ID automatically assigned. If you provide a complete key, the entity will be updated with the data specified.

By default, all properties are indexed. To prevent a property from being included in all indexes, you must supply an entity's data property as an array. See below for an example.

examples.caption: Save a single entity. Notice that we are providing an incomplete key. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with its generated ID.

Save a single entity using a provided name instead of auto-generated ID. Here we are providing a key with name instead of an ID. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with the name instead of a generated ID.

Save a single entity with a provided namespace. Namespaces allow for multitenancy. To read more about this, see [the Datastore docs on key concepts](https://goo.gl/M1LUAu). Here we are providing a key with namespace.

Save different types of data, including ints, doubles, dates, booleans, blobs, and lists. Notice that we are providing an incomplete key. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with its generated ID.
To specify an excludeFromIndexes value for a Datastore entity, pass in an array for the key's data. The above example would then look like:
Save multiple entities at once.
Explicitly attempt to 'insert' a specific entity.

params.name: entities.method
params.description: • Optional method to explicity use for save. The choices include 'insert', 'update', 'upsert' and 'insert_auto_id'.

params.name: entities.data
params.description: • Data to save with the provided key. If you provide an array of objects, you must use the explicit syntax: name for the name of the property and value for its value. You may also specify an excludeFromIndexes property, set to true or false.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: delete
methods.description: Delete all entities identified with the specified key(s).

examples.code: dataset.delete(dataset.key(['Company', 123]), function(err, apiResp) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
examples.code: transaction.delete(dataset.key(['Company', 123]), function(err, apiResp) {});

examples.caption: Delete multiple entities at once.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: runQuery
methods.description:
Datastore allows you to query entities by kind, filter them by property filters, and sort them by a property name. Projection and pagination are also supported.

If you provide a callback, the query is run, and the results are returned as the second argument to your callback. A third argument may also exist, which is a query object that uses the end cursor from the previous query as the starting cursor for the next query. You can pass that object back to this method to see if more results exist.

You may also omit the callback to this function to trigger streaming mode.

See below for examples of both approaches.

examples.caption: Where you see transaction, assume this is the context that's relevant to your use, whether that be a Dataset or a Transaction object.
examples.code:
var query = dataset.createQuery('Lion');

dataset.runQuery(query, function(err, entities) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
examples.code: transaction.runQuery(query, function(err, entities) {});

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, call autoPaginate(false) on your query.
If you omit the callback, runQuery will automatically call subsequent queries until no results remain. Entity objects will be pushed as they are found.
A keys-only query returns just the keys of the result entities instead of the entities themselves, at lower latency and cost.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function. If omitted, a readable stream instance is returned.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request (may be null).

params.name: callback.entities
params.description: • The list of entities returned by this query. Note that this is a single page of entities, not necessarily all of the entities.

params.name: callback.nextQuery
params.description: • If present, run another query with this object to check for more results.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.nextQuery
params.description: • If present, query with this object to check for more results.

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: update
methods.description: Maps to datastore/dataset#save, forcing the method to be update.

methods.name: upsert
methods.description: Maps to datastore/dataset#save, forcing the method to be upsert.
